comments.commentBody: A Romney finger is in every pot. It's very creepy!

Maybe we should revert to paper ballots, put into sealed boxes at the polling station, and hand counted by teams after delivery to a central location.  We might not know the winner for a day or two, and certainly the 10PM newsreaders would have to find something else to talk about, but there would be no reason for concern about a candidate corrupting the count.  In truth, there hasn't been, and won't soon be, a perfect election system, and while the suggestion above was not entirely serious, there is much to be said for avoiding black boxes with complex and secret inner workings in favor of fundamentally simple and transparent procedures.

It may be that the ways of buying an election can get much more sinister than what you are talking about here.

For example, people backing one of the candidates can, before an election, buy companies that build the voting machines. And as we know, if you own the voting machines, all kinds of sinister possibilities exist.

Vote counting company Hart Intercivic, whose machines have famously failed in the past, is tied to Mitt Romney and Bain Capital.

See CORRUPTION: Bain-Controlled Company Owns 2012 Voting Machines
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sasfm_fTuyQ

In my experience, many government agencies are overstaffed with underqualified, undermotivated people. Let's cut staff and hire people who are willing to push harder to get the work done.  Service will improve, at a lower cost, and the people who are let go can go to the private sector to see how the other half lives.

There are some huge risks for second guessing Klinsi if these choices blow up in his face.
Eddie Johnson I can actually see with his form, but Alan Gordon? It's not like Wondo *can't* score with his head.
Donovan came out of the loss against RSL claiming injury, and he's included. Michael Bradley is just back from injury himself, and didn't go the full 90 against Atalanta. Meanwhile, Jermaine Jones not only didn't play Saturday against Wolfsburg, he didn't play in the CL against Montpellier, and wasn't even on the subs bench for either match, but he's in.
Kyle Beckerman? Just a mancrush by the gaffer. Maybe he's got a weakness for dreads. Both of these matches should, nay, must be invitations for scoring. If Klinsi plays a midfield with Beckerman, Bradley and Jones, with Dempsey and Donovan flanking Gomez, well, there are certainly goals from the men up top, but service? And fullback support to the offense?
The A & B match will be a mystery to me, without BeInSports, but I will be yelling at the TV seriously if the Guatemala match is a one goal affair late on, but I don't think it would surprise me.

The same principle holds throughout human and, indeed, natural experience. The attempt to pin down meaning like a butterfly often just destroys the flutter-by. Philosophy delved into dialectic and definitions, syntax and sense in this futile effort. Science is the perfect example of a discipline which cannot finally prove anything exactly, but only offer a helix of hypothesis spiraling off into further studies and more extensive understanding. Birds have no need of defining cat, but only cry a warning as they flee. And to contemplate the eerie howls of the canine species is attempting to plumb the depths of the mortal predicament. Whales communicate across oceans with plaintive, playful, mourning and alarming musings. So meaning is in context, in the attempt to understand, itself. The Ninth Amendment reserving all rights unspecified, may be the Constitution's finest. Attempts like Justice Scalia's to extract the marrow from these bones imitate an institutional discipline which melds a sublime moral doctrine into an engine to exploit and enslave.

pj, you are incorrect. According to the New York Times' own article (http://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/14/garden/14lead.html, the average level of lead in unpolluted soil is 10 ppm - we are constantly exposed to it. Fortunately, this level is sufficiently low such that, unless one's children or oneself exclusively exists on a diet of dirt, it is harmless.

Timothy--A one-time encounter with 0.015 mg/L may be OK. Unfortunately lead tends to accumulate in the human body when there are repeated exposures to it.  It's important to take that into account when assessing safety. Unless planning to have only one or two exposures at the level the EPA considers safe, ZERO is the only safe level. When lead accumulates, it can cause mental impairments, even retardation in children.

Actually, after working at The Boeing Company, it works like this-- due to continual cost containment, and FAA requirements, all aircraft are required to be pulled apart after something like 10,000 flight hours, to fix and repair stress fractures. It's a very laborious process which used to be completed in the US. Anyways, a new industry in China popped up to address this, called MROs. MRO companies such as Lufthansa-Technik in China, and Airbus, now do all of the FAA Required D-Checks (Heavy Maintenance Visit "HMV") in China due to cheap labor.

To perform a HMV or D-Check, Boeing has to provide entire manufacturing process, diagrams, and technical data to companies in China, so they can take the aircraft apart and put it completely back together. It takes 2-3 months to do this process.

China doesn't need to buy a single US airplane to get the knowledge to build one exactly. Boeing has to give it to them, as a part of FAA Compliance checks.
No one is obligating chinese comapnies to buy anything, right?  Presumably if they're buying boeing, for example, it's because it's either a better product, a better price, or both.
So I guess it would be ok for Chinese companies not to buy Boeing or other high tech equipment.
Oops! That's Sotsialisticheskikh.
Glad you caught that, Rijk.

CCCP is of course short for Сою́з Сове́тских Социалисти́ческих Респу́блик or transliterated Soyuz Sovietskikh Sotsialistichekikh Respublik.  I studied Russian in High School and later became a Russian linguist in the Navy.  I remember hearing Dick Cavett pronounce the country's name on his show back around 1970.  He did a good job!

Actually, the query list would often not find the correct person unless you had the decedent's Social Security number. What often happens, particularly in cases where the decedent lived to be 80 or older, is that the person relaying the information doesn't know all of it. For instance, if I am looking for a Harold James Johnson, who I believe was born in Wisconsin and died in Arizona, I may have to spend quite a bit if time looking through not only those people who exactly fit those criteria, but also through all of the Harold James Johnson's, the Harold J. Johnson's, and the Harold Johnson's.
This can happen because the daughter-in-law or grandchild who ends up dealing with matters never knew Mr. Johnson's middle name or that he was actually born in Minnesota because his mother wanted him to be delivered by her cousin.

"I would like to patient the use of heat to warm food and the use of tables to serve the food". Or writing. "I would like to patient the use of irony to describe situations." What I'm saying is, some of these patients are extremely broad. This commenting system probably infringes on patients that someone filed somewhere. It's ridiculous.

He's no Bird, but then who could even come close? Still, it's refreshing to see some oddball re-introduced to Baseball. What does Crash Davis say in "Bull Durham" -- "this game is fun, it's fun goddamit!"

And anything is better than watching the utter joylessness with which the NY Bankees (no spelling error, by the way) play. If you want some real laughs, compare their celebration of winning the AL East with the A's winning the AL West. Wow, someone really needs to quote Crash Davis to the Bankees!

Why not grow fruits and vegetables in containers? Or how about building raised beds with a barrier between the good soil in the raised bed and the existing bad soil underneath? You could buy good compost from an organic garden center or make your own to put in the raised bed or containers. Lots of good books and gardening magazines on how to do this. You could also build a cold frame or get special thermal blankets to put over plants to keep them warm. Lucky you, living in a climate that gets cold enough in winter for growing wild blueberries. They have absolutely the best flavor in the world.

Pica includes the eating of any non-nutritive substances for more than a month for the diagnosis of pica. Non-nutritive substances include paint chips, clay, soil and even dog waste, which is how some children get hookworms, too. The article states that lead is in the NYC soil, so children can get lead from eating either or both lead-contaminated paint chips and/or soil that's contaminated by lead from gasoline. Soil tests are likely to reveal lead contamination of soil almost anywhere in the U.S. due of the use of tetraethyl lead in gasoline.

children who eat paint chips do not necessarily have the disorder known as pica
remember
oxides of lead (found in paint tints)
taste sweet!

Otherwise too novel could not have similar incidents or relationships- obviously if the plot is the same, the original author could claim infringement. Patenting rounded corners and images of trash cans is not just ridiculous but predatory.
